title: Sun shut down Mystics, force Game 5 in WNBA Finals
text:
Holding Washington scoreless in the last 2:10, the Connecticut Sun forced a decisive Game 5 of the WNBA Finals with a 90-86 win Tuesday over the visiting Mystics at Uncasville, Conn.

Now tied at 2-2, the final game of the best-of-five series will be Thursday in Washington, D.C.

Alyssa Thomas had 17 points, 11 assists and eight rebounds, and Jonquel Jones finished with 18 points and 13 rebounds to lead Connecticut.

The teams traded 3-pointers on three successive possessions, the last coming on Shekinna Stricklen's shot with 2:23 left to give the Sun an 87-84 lead with 2:23 left in regulation. Natasha Cloud answered for Washington with a layup in the following possession with 2:10 left.

After three failed possessions each, Jasmine Thomas made two free throws with 18.4 seconds left to put the Sun ahead 89-86. Cloud missed on the other end and Alyssa Thomas was fouled. She made one of two free throw attempts with 10 seconds left.

Connecticut made 23 of 26 free throw attempts.

On Washington's final attempt, Emma Meesseman missed a layup with 6.4 seconds left.

The Mystics had five scorers in double figures led by Aerial Powers' 15 off the bench. Ariel Atkins had 14 points and Meesseman had all 12 of her points in the second half.

Elena Delle Donne, playing through a back injury, had 11 points in 30 minutes. Cloud added 13 points, nine assists and seven rebounds.

Washington, which made a WNBA-record 16 3-pointers in the Game 3 win Sunday, was only 5 of 12 from beyond the arc in the first half as Connecticut took a 56-40 halftime lead. The Mystics shot 44.1 percent from the field and were outrebounded 22-12 in the first half. Connecticut had a 13-0 edge in second-chance points in the half.

Alyssa Thomas and Courtney Williams each had 14 points to lead the Sun by halftime.

Connecticut built an early 11-3 lead and extended that to 30-12 with 1:35 left in the first quarter. Williams had eight points and Thomas seven assists in the first quarter.

The Mystics went on a 16-1 run to start the third quarter to cut Connecticut's lead to 57-56 with 5:29 left. The Sun started the half missing their first six shots.

Connecticut responded with a 7-0 run to increase the lead to 66-58 with 3:30 remaining in the third quarter. That's when Meesseman, who had 21 points in the Game 3 win, made her first two shots to fuel a 6-0 spurt to get Washington back in it at 66-64 with 1:43 left in the quarter.

The score was tied at 68 entering the fourth quarter as Washington outscored Connecticut 28-12 in the third period.

--Field Level Media
